issue.title: lib/db: Improve error handling checking db (ref #7026)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

milestone.title: v1.11.0
milestone.description: This release adds the `sendFullIndexOnUpgrade` option to control whether all index data is resent when an upgrade is detected, equivalent to starting Syncthing with `--reset-deltas`. This (`sendFullIndexOnUpgrade=true`) used to be the behavior in previous versions, but is mainly useful as a troubleshooting step and causes high database churn. The new default is `false`.

issue.body:
Adds context to the errors in `getMetaAndCheck` to know where it originates from.

Also ignores not found errors when deleting in `checkLocalNeed`. I don't think we should ever get such errors there, but they are the only possible source I see for the panics in #7026, and it doesn't hurt.

body: (GitHub has been sending me angry emails about the sentry integration using some deprecated API. We may want to upgrade it at some point.)

Me too. And the sentry integration itself is deprecated, in favor of global apps (but it looks like we are already using that?): https://github.com/getsentry/sentry/tree/master/src/sentry_plugins/github Can't look into it as I don't have sentry admin access.
The integration is only used to associate commits with reported events, which was always a hit and miss (mostly a miss), so I am not sure if it matters?

This issue/panic report has now suddenly disappeared from sentry. The link above points to something completely different and a search turns up only old stuff: https://sentry.syncthing.net/syncthing/syncthing/?query=key+not+found No clue what's going on.

The reports are there in the original, so it wasn't just you hallucinating anyway.

(then I stopped grepping)

I think mystery solved on the "disappeared" sentry issue:  
Database corruptions lead to the same trace and were matched together with the `panic: key not found` events. Those events can still be found when looking at the events list. Probably sentry matches on trace alone, not the panic message (which is bad), and uses the latest message to name the event.  
So yeah, issue reopened.

And yes the github integration is broken, but as said before that's not really important.
We control the fingerprint so could decide how we merge the events.

I was about to include the message in the fingerprint, but it requires a bit more finesse. Otherwise a ton of new (-ly separate) issues of the form of `panic: filling Blocks: leveldb/table: corruption on data-block (pos=44628228): checksum mismatch, want=0xc0cf30b4 got=0x9904896c [file=059189.ldb]` will pop up. Same for out of range panics and possibly more.

issue.title: lib/db: Handle indirection error repairing sequences (fixes #7026)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

milestone.title: v1.16.0
milestone.description: This release adds untrusted / encrypted devices for public testing. It should still be considered beta / testing-only.

issue.body:
#7026 is about unspecific `key not found` errors on sentry. The only one that still gets events is https://sentry.syncthing.net/share/issue/270bbc681e3943f7a121268553e6f2e5/, and that's what I am addressing here:

`panic: repairing sequences: filling Blocks: key not found`

When repairing sequences all local files are deserialized, and apparently sometimes the blocks are indirected (or look like it), but theirs no entry for the hash. Instead of failing db repair and thus making the db entirely broken, the defective file info is now removed from the db - to be rescanned later.

Some related changes: I moved checking/repairing globals out of `recalcMeta` into `getMetaAndCheck`. Having that happen as a side effect of recalculating metadata is plain confusing (and I probably wrote that code :) ).  
And the db migration 15 (which uses `recalcMeta`), is redundant with 16 (the meta just gets recalculated twice) - thus removed.
